The drawback is that the deduction doesn't apply to all taxpayers. That it disproportionately goes to higher-income taxpayers is a consequence of its design but not itself an intrinsic flaw. Giving ought to be safeguarded against taxation among lower-class Americans as well.

The after-tax price of #giving (the value of donations minus the deduction) declines with income. Thus, even if low- and high-income taxpayers donated the same amount and itemized, the latter would still receive a greater charitable deduction. http://pbs.twimg.com/media/EROvm1SU0AETKCh.jpg http://pbs.twimg.com/media/EROvm04X0AMaAzT.jpg

However, because itemizers tend to have higher incomes, the charitable deduction overwhelmingly goes to higher-income taxpayers. Over 56% of the charitable giving that avoided taxation because of the deduction came from the top 1% of Americans. #Charity http://pbs.twimg.com/media/EROvkMRWsAAHhro.jpg

This presidential power is available to all presidents in all cases brought before our justice system.

This is the way our legal system is intended to work and provides a brilliant and intricate system of checks and balances we should all honor.
Under our system of justice President Trump has all the legal authority in the world to review this case, in terms of commuting the sentence or pardoning Mr. Stone for the underlying offense.

It is important to give both the government and the accused a fair trial free from influence.  

I believe this has been accomplished in Mr. Stone‚Äôs case.  

Like all Americans, Mr. Stone can appeal the fairness of his trial and the verdict rendered.
The sentence rendered in the Roger Stone case by Judge Jackson is on the lower end of the recommended sentencing guidelines for offenses of this nature.
